They could add shielding as a tweakable, so you could 'dial-a-heat-shield'. This would be (IMHO) the only sensible way to do shielding for space planes and shuttles, which would find it very hard to attach independent heat shields. Obviously this could cost funds and mass, and maybe not be available on all parts.

Alternatively, they could add integral heat shields to the capsules, as DRE does with the Mk 1, and adjust the mass appropriately. This would only apply to certain parts, and not to others (for example the lander cans).

Alternatively again, they could implement independent shields that could be attached as any other part. This would allow them to be detached (either with a built-in decoupler or a regular one) allowing for a great variety of designs, but OTOH would add to part count.

I haven't seen anything from SQUAD to indicate which method (or combination of methods) they prefer. I'm pretty sure that they do plan to implement *some* kind of shielding, though, otherwise adding aerodynamic heating would be pretty pointless, as you say.
I'm imagining that heatshields aren't posible for spaceplanes - we're just going to have to be careful about re-entering slowly.

That would be ... harsh.

Currently with Deadly Re-Entry it isn't difficult to bring the science home. Goo canisters can easily be placed behind other parts so as to not expose them to re-entry effects. Likewise Materials Labs can have heat shields added to them. Also, coming in slowly (say after a low orbit circularizing burn) reduces the heat a great deal and most stock components can survive re-entry without problem.

> 
> Currently with Deadly Re-Entry it isn't difficult to bring the science home. Goo canisters can easily be placed behind other parts so as to not expose them to re-entry effects. Likewise Materials Labs can have heat shields added to them. Also, coming in slowly (say after a low orbit circularizing burn) reduces the heat a great deal and most stock components can survive re-entry without problem.

Also, if you save some fuel, you can do a second retrograde burn during the heating portion of the descent (25-35km I think) to slow down faster and get below the extra-crispy speed sooner. Hopefully before something overheats.

IIRC a realistsic reentry on Kerbin should not produce a lot of heat: not enough atmosphere, things are over quickly. The DRE folks had to crank up some values, otherwise there would be no need for an D in DRE.

But as I said: IIRC. I can't find a post to quote from.
